headline: U.S. yield curve prices for Fed tightening, shows fears of policy error
author: Karen Brettell Reuters
sentences: A dramatic flattening in key parts of the U.S. Treasury yield curve is reflecting worries that the Federal Reserve has been too slow to raise interest rates and will now risk causing a recession by tightening monetary policy too aggressively.

In this case, investors believe the flattening yield curve reflects worries that the Fed has already let inflation get out of control by being slow off the mark in raising interest rates and risks hurting growth as it hurries to catch up.

"On the one hand, the market is saying this is what the Fed is going to be doing, and on the other side it's saying 'oh by the way, it's going to be a mistake,'" said Tom Fitzpatrick, chief technical strategist at Citi.
The Fed can also use the roll off or possible sale of bonds from its massive balance sheet to tighten conditions, or to re-steepen curves and give it more space to keep hiking rates.
The two-year, 10-year yield curve is the most closely watched as a recession indicator, with an economic downturn seen as likely six months to two years after this part inverts.
Investors are now pricing in around 175 basis points of interest rate increases by next February and a 62% chance the Fed will raise rates 50 basis points at its March meeting.
The gap between yields on two-year and 10-year U.S. government debt is the smallest since July 2020 and compressed sharply after the latest inflation was released Feb. 10.
"The bond market is saying that we're in a bit of a boom here and the Fed has a lot of work to do," said Padhraic Garvey, regional head of research, Americas, at ING.
Expectations for a flatter yield curve were the highest since 2005, though only 12% of respondents said a recession will occur within the next year.
An inverted curve, where rates on short-term government debt exceed those on longer-term debt, has reliably predicted past recessions.
Fund managers in a BofA Global Research survey, released last week, named hawkish central banks as the top "tail risk" to markets.
While the flattening curve is attracting attention, most market participants don't see a recession on the horizon.
A rate hike of at least 25 basis points in March is fully priced in.
Investors watch the yield curve for insight into the U.S. economy.
